awd_titl_txt: Belmont Forum Collaborative Research: Building New Tools for Data Sharing and Re-use through a Transnational Investigation of the Socioeconomic Impacts of Protected Areas (PARSEC)
awd_abstract_narration:
The capability to bring computer science and technology as well as large and complex data sets to bear on interdisciplinary and transdisciplinary science is emerging. It is therefore critically important to establish and enable transnational frameworks so that data-driven scientific knowledge can transcend disciplines and geographical borders, ultimately increasing the scientific underpinnings of policy and action. International collaboration within global environmental change research fields holds the potential to establish international foundations for federated data integration and analysis systems with shared services, bring together best practices from the public and private sectors, foster open data and open science stewardship among the science communities including related areas such as publishing, and encourage data and cloud providers and others to adopt common standards and practices for the benefit of all.

This award supports U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by a coalition of 29 funding agencies from 23 countries through the Belmont Forum Call for proposals on "Science-driven e-Infrastructure Innovation (SEI) for the Enhancement of Transnational, Interdisciplinary and Transdisciplinary Data Use in Environmental Change".  SEI is a multilateral initiative designed to support research projects that bring together environmental, social and economic scientists with data scientists, computational scientists, and e-infrastructure and cyber-infrastructure developers and providers to solve one or more of the methodological, technological and/or procedural challenges currently facing inter-disciplinary and transdisciplinary environmental change research that involves working with large, diverse and multi-source transnational data. The SEI call will intimately link research thinking and technological innovation toward accelerating the full-path of discovery-driven data use and open science and enable a broader scientific community to benefit from the identified new and potentially disruptive demonstrators or pilots toward solutions.

Scientific advances depend on the availability, accessibility and reusability of data, software, samples, and data products. Yet large amounts of data on the Earth are not well preserved or preserved at all. This project will address these questions by supporting the collaboration of a synthesis science team and data-science team. The teams will conduct a trans-disciplinary, trans-national synthesis science project in parallel and in partnership with a project on the use and re-use of environmental and socioeconomic data to assess practices for managing and preserving data. The project will provide a unique opportunity for data scientists and synthesis scientists to collaborate in real-time toward the goal of improving research outcomes and data sharing. In partnership with teams in France, Brazil, the United States, Japan, Australia, and the United Kingdom, the project will examine the socioeconomic effects of natural protected areas on local communities. The resulting tools and metrics will enable better prediction and mitigation of the effect of actions that disrupt historical land use practices. The project team will develop leading practices on data citation, attribution, credit, and reuse. With these new practices as the content, a toolkit and workshop materials to deliver the content via face-to-face meetings and webinars will be created as will a tool for researchers to view their shared data, data usage and reuse through widgets and on-line profiles. The project results will be useful to circa 300,000 earth, space, and environmental researchers worldwide. It will advance the momentum of cultural change in the use and re-use of big data in research on real-world problems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project, Building New Tools for Data Sharing and Reuse through a Transnational Investigation of the Socioeconomic Impacts of Protected Areas (PARSEC), is a transdisciplinary, multinational team with specialists in data science, data management, image analysis, artificial intelligence, machine learning, deep learning, spatial systems, socioeconomics, wildlife biology, and ecology from Brazil, France, Japan, Australia, and the United States. 

The PARSEC team examined the influence of marine and terrestrial protected areas on socioeconomic outcomes in the surrounding communities. The approach used existing data, combining satellite and other remotely sensed data with socioeconomic data using artificial intelligence and other tools. Throughout its core scientific investigation, the project promoted best practices for data and software management, such as preparing them properly for reuse and for preservation in a trusted repository with proper attribution. 

The PARSEC objectives are aligned with the global Open Science initiatives and led to a pivotal effort building Open Science capacity and expertise across the five different countries.

Openly *see* linkages between publications and datasets

The PARSEC Data Science team, led by AGU’s VP of Open Science Leadership, Shelley Stall, addressed significant data sharing infrastructure problems with published datasets. In 2019, it was not possible to “see” how your research was linked to your cited dataset nor its reuse.  The scholarly communication infrastructure did not include the necessary metadata or connections to show this information. We developed requirements in partnership with the DataCite registry agency to update their metadata and provide two products:  1) a website where datasets could be *seen* connected to publications - this has further evolved to the DataCite Commons, and 2) a widget that can be used by data repositories to share usage and citation information extending the work of MakeDataCount. The widget is now known as the DataCite Usage Tracker. Both of these were initially delivered in 2020 and provided the basic infrastructure to “see” linkages between publications and the supporting datasets in the same way that referenced journals are linked to new research. DataCite Commons is used by thousands of researchers.

Getting started in Open Science

An assumption the team made when we crafted the proposal was that materials existed for researchers to help them with the first steps in Open Science: understanding persistent identifiers for researchers, specifically ORCID, and documentation and citation of data and software. We knew that the informatics community had several excellent sources, and felt they would work for researchers. A short time into the project it was clear that those materials would not integrate into the research lifecycle the way we intended. They used vocabulary understood by informatics practitioners and did not frame the value statement researchers needed to encourage adoption.  And so, with close consultation of the 40+ researchers on the PARSEC team, we developed multi-lingual, multi-disciplinary, multinational content: Your Open Science Journey. It includes two sets of checklists: 

For the researcher: resources to help them get recognition for their work and make sure their work and profile are visible and discoverable.

For a research team or lab: guidance to help them learn to work openly and collaboratively - an important element for muliti-disciplinary and multinational teams.

 

These resources are available in English, French, Japanese, Portuguese, Chinese, and Spanish. We have developed companion workshop materials that accommodate different learning formats. We have delivered this content at society meetings associated with Earth, space, and environmental sciences as well as guest lecturer for numerous institutions. The process of translating together as a team, specifically communicating new concepts like Open Science, led to a publication to help others. The resources have been accessed by over 10 thousand researchers. 

Data and Digital Object Management (and Sharing) Workbook

Two of the primary goals for the Belmont Forum funded cohort where PARSEC is one of the funded projects were to 1) promote data reuse and 2) use the new Belmont Forum requirements for their Data and Digital Output Management Plan (DDOMP). The PARSEC team converted the plan to a workbook with “researcher guidance” to help understand the purpose of each element and make good decisions. We also re-interpreted the plan to include the entire research lifecycle, so that digital object management and sharing were included from the beginning and viewed as normal procedure through the research project and not a burden at the end. We updated our workbook at least once a year during the project, developed a checklist, and shared all the tools we used to manage the work during the project. The PARSEC DDOMP workbook has been accessed over a thousand times. We published our experience to help others. This content integrates nicely with the Journey to Open Science. The team received a funding supplement to develop four learning modules for any research team, most especially those funded by the Belmont Forum, to integrate digital object management into their research project.
